title: Germans and Americans express diminishing confidence in U.S. government's treatment of rights The U.S. government respects the personal.freedoms of
question: Describe the trend in the number of Germans and Americans that thinks the U.S. respects personal freedoms.
Gold Standard: since 2013 , there has been a steady decline in both Germany and America in the percentage of those saying the U.S. government respects the personal freedoms of its people . In that year , 81 % of Germans and 69 % of Americans said the U.S. government respected the personal freedoms of its people . But after multiple scandals involving the exposure of National Security Agency eavesdropping , confidence in American respect for civil liberties began to decline . Now , just 35 % of Germans and 51 % of Americans hold this view
T5_BBOX: Currently, 58 % of Germans say the U.S. government respects the personal freedoms of its people.

title: Satisfaction with National Conditi ons
question: Compare the national satisfaction of different nations?
Gold Standard: More than seven - in - ten Chinese citizens ( 72 % ) express satisfaction with their national condition , while fewer than one - in - five ( 19 % ) are dissatisfied . On this score , China far outstrips India , where only 41 % say they are content with national conditions . And in China , the level of satisfaction is more than three times higher than in Russia , where only 23 % are pleased with their country ’s direction .
T5_BBOX: In China, 72 % express satisfaction with the way things are going in their country, compared with 69 % in Jordan and 57 % in Pakistan. In Spain, 51 % express satisfaction with the way things are going in their country. In the Netherlands, 49 % express satisfaction with the way things are going in their country. In the U.S., 58 % express satisfaction with the way things are going in their country.
T5: More than seven - in - ten Chinese citizens ( 72 % ) express satisfaction with their national condition, while fewer than one - in - five ( 19 % ) are dissatisfied. China far outstrips India, where only 41 % say they are content with national conditions. And in China, the level of satisfaction is more than three times higher than in Russia, where only 23 % are pleased with their country ’s direction.

title: Democrats now about as likely to sympathize with Palestinians as Israel side do you sympathize with more? (%) Democrats
question: Tell some information about Democrats now about as likely to sympathize with Palestinians as Israel side do you sympathize with more?
Gold Standard: For the first time in Pew Research Center surveys , Democrats are about as likely to say they sympathize more with the Palestinians ( 31 % ) than with Israel ( 33 % ) ; 11 % say they sympathize with neither , while 8 % sympathize with both and 17 % do not offer an opinion . The share of Democrats who say they sympathize more with Israel is down 10 points from April 2016 . The share who say they sympathize more with the Palestinians is little changed from last April ( 29 % ) , but is up significantly from July 2014 when just 17 % said they sympathized more with the Palestinians . By contrast , Republicans continue to overwhelmingly say they sympathize more with Israel ( 74 % ) than the Palestinians ( 11 % ) . There has been little movement in views among Republicans in recent years , but the share who say they sympathize more with Israel is now higher than in the mid-2000s and prior . For example , in 2005 , 57 % of Republicans said they sympathized more with Israel in their dispute with the Palestinians . As a result of these trends , there is now a 41 - point gap between the shares of Republicans ( 74 % ) and Democrats ( 33 % ) who say they sympathize more with Israel .
T5_BBOX: Democrats are now about as likely to sympathize with the Palestinians as they are to sympathize with Israel ( 33 % vs. 38 % ).
T5: For the first time in Pew Research Center surveys, Democrats are about as likely to say they sympathize more with the Palestinians ( 31 % ) than with Israel ( 33 % ) ; 11 % say they sympathize with neither, while 8 % sympathize with both and 17 % do not offer an opinion.

title: Share of adults living in middle-income households is unchanged since 2011
question: Describe the changes in American income level from 1971 to 2011?
Gold Standard: From 1971 to 2011 , the share of adults in the middle class fell by 10 percentage points . But that shift was not all down the economic ladder . The increase in the share of adults who are upper income was greater than the increase in the share who are lower income over that period , a sign of economic progress overall .
T5_BBOX: From 1971 to 2011, the share of adults living in middle - income households has remained unchanged. In 2011, 59 % of adults lived in middle - income households, up from 29 % in 1971.
T5: About half ( 52 % ) of American adults lived in middle - class households in 2016. This is virtually unchanged from the 51 % who were middle class in 2011.

title: Social networking site use by age group, 2005-2011 The percentage of adult internet users in each age group who use social networking sites
question: How is the use of social networks characterized by different age groups?
Gold Standard: Social networking sites have been very popular with young adults ages 18 - 29 almost since their inception . Between February 2005 and August 2006 , the use of social networking sites among young adult internet users ages 18 - 29 jumped from 9 % to 49 % ; during this same time period , use of these sites by 30 - 49 year olds remained essentially unchanged . Since then , users under age 30 have continued to be significantly more likely to use social networking sites when compared with every other adult age group . As of May 2011 , over eight in ten internet users ages 18 - 29 use social networking sites ( 83 % ) , compared with seven in ten 30 - 49 year - olds ( 70 % ) , half of 50 - 64 year - olds ( 51 % ) , and a third of those age 65 and older ( 33 % ) .
T5_BBOX: The share of internet users ages 65 and older who use social networking sites has risen significantly in recent years. In 2005, 83 % of internet users ages 65 and older used social networking sites, compared with 61 % of internet users ages 18 to 29. In 2011, the share of internet users ages 30 to 49 increased to 47 %.
T5: Social networking sites have been very popular with young adults ages 18 - 29 almost since their inception. title: Social networking site use by age group, 2005-2011 The percentage of adult internet users in each age group who use social networking sites
question: How is the use of social networks characterized by different age groups?
Gold Standard: Social networking sites have been very popular with young adults ages 18 - 29 almost since their inception . Between February 2005 and August 2006 , the use of social networking sites among young adult internet users ages 18 - 29 jumped from 9 % to 49 % ; during this same time period , use of these sites by 30 - 49 year olds remained essentially unchanged . Since then , users under age 30 have continued to be significantly more likely to use social networking sites when compared with every other adult age group . As of May 2011 , over eight in ten internet users ages 18 - 29 use social networking sites ( 83 % ) , compared with seven in ten 30 - 49 year - olds ( 70 % ) , half of 50 - 64 year - olds ( 51 % ) , and a third of those age 65 and older ( 33 % ) .
T5_BBOX: The share of internet users ages 65 and older who use social networking sites has risen significantly in recent years. In 2005, 83 % of internet users ages 65 and older used social networking sites, compared with 61 % of internet users ages 18 to 29. In 2011, the share of internet users ages 30 to 49 increased to 47 %.

title: Russian Views of China and the U.S. Russians with afavorable view of
question: How have Russians' views of China and the U.S. changed?
Gold Standard: China is gaining popularity in Russia as attitudes toward the U.S. turn sharply negative . In just the past two years , favorable views of China have jumped 17 percentage points among Russians , from 62 % in 2013 to an all - time high of 79 % today . Meanwhile , favorable views of the U.S. have taken a nosedive , falling from 51 % in 2013 , to 23 % in 2014 , to an all - time low of 15 % today .
T5_BBOX: Currently, 71 % of Russians have a favorable view of China, while 61 % have a favorable view of the U.S.
T5: In just the past two years, favorable views of China have jumped 17 percentage points among Russians, from 62 % in 2013 to an all - time high of 79 % today. Meanwhile, favorable views of the U.S. have taken a nosedive, falling from 51 % in 2013, to 23 % in 2014, to an all - time low of 15 % today.

title: Democrats now about as likely to sympathize with Palestinians as Israel side do you sympathize with more? (%) Democrats
question: Tell some information about Democrats now about as likely to sympathize with Palestinians as Israel side do you sympathize with more?
Gold Standard: For the first time in Pew Research Center surveys , Democrats are about as likely to say they sympathize more with the Palestinians ( 31 % ) than with Israel ( 33 % ) ; 11 % say they sympathize with neither , while 8 % sympathize with both and 17 % do not offer an opinion . The share of Democrats who say they sympathize more with Israel is down 10 points from April 2016 . The share who say they sympathize more with the Palestinians is little changed from last April ( 29 % ) , but is up significantly from July 2014 when just 17 % said they sympathized more with the Palestinians . By contrast , Republicans continue to overwhelmingly say they sympathize more with Israel ( 74 % ) than the Palestinians ( 11 % ) . There has been little movement in views among Republicans in recent years , but the share who say they sympathize more with Israel is now higher than in the mid-2000s and prior . For example , in 2005 , 57 % of Republicans said they sympathized more with Israel in their dispute with the Palestinians . As a result of these trends , there is now a 41 - point gap between the shares of Republicans ( 74 % ) and Democrats ( 33 % ) who say they sympathize more with Israel .
T5_BBOX: Democrats are now about as likely to sympathize with the Palestinians as they are to sympathize with Israel ( 33 % vs. 38 % ).
T5: For the first time in Pew Research Center surveys, Democrats are about as likely to say they sympathize more with the Palestinians ( 31 % ) than with Israel ( 33 % ) ; 11 % say they sympathize with neither, while 8 % sympathize with both and 17 % do not offer an opinion.

Non - Muslims are less likely to rate Muslims as greedy or immoral — in France for instance , only 10 % say Muslims are greedy and just 18 % label Muslims as immoral . The data on Muslim attitudes towards Westerners also reveal a variety of negative views . In the five majority Muslim countries , as well as Nigeria , at least 40 % of Muslims characterize Westerners as arrogant , violent , greedy , and immoral ; meanwhile , relatively few say Westerners are generous or honest . Muslims in these countries are also especially likely to say Westerners are selfish — in all six countries , majorities suggest selfishness is common among people in Europe and the United States . Negative assessments of Westerners are fairly common across all six of these countries , although they are slightly more prevalent in Jordan and Indonesia .

question: How is the use of social networks characterized by different age groups?
Gold Standard: Social networking sites have been very popular with young adults ages 18 - 29 almost since their inception . Since then , users under age 30 have continued to be significantly more likely to use social networking sites when compared with every other adult age group . As of May 2011 , over eight in ten internet users ages 18 - 29 use social networking sites ( 83 % ) , compared with seven in ten 30 - 49 year - olds ( 70 % ) , half of 50 - 64 year - olds ( 51 % ) , and a third of those age 65 and older ( 33 % ) .

In 2011, the share of internet users ages 30 to 49 increased to 47 %.

title: Democrats now about as likely to sympathize with Palestinians as Israel side do you sympathize with more? (%) Democrats
question: Tell some information about Democrats now about as likely to sympathize with Palestinians as Israel side do you sympathize with more?
Gold Standard: For the first time in Pew Research Center surveys , Democrats are about as likely to say they sympathize more with the Palestinians ( 31 % ) than with Israel ( 33 % ) ; 11 % say they sympathize with neither , while 8 % sympathize with both and 17 % do not offer an opinion . The share of Democrats who say they sympathize more with Israel is down 10 points from April 2016 . The share who say they sympathize more with the Palestinians is little changed from last April ( 29 % ) , but is up significantly from July 2014 when just 17 % said they sympathized more with the Palestinians . By contrast , Republicans continue to overwhelmingly say they sympathize more with Israel ( 74 % ) than the Palestinians ( 11 % ) . There has been little movement in views among Republicans in recent years , but the share who say they sympathize more with Israel is now higher than in the mid-2000s and prior . For example , in 2005 , 57 % of Republicans said they sympathized more with Israel in their dispute with the Palestinians . As a result of these trends , there is now a 41 - point gap between the shares of Republicans ( 74 % ) and Democrats ( 33 % ) who say they sympathize more with Israel .
T5_BBOX: Democrats are now about as likely to sympathize with the Palestinians as they are to sympathize with Israel ( 33 % vs. 38 % ).
T5: For the first time in Pew Research Center surveys, Democrats are about as likely to say they sympathize more with the Palestinians ( 31 % ) than with Israel ( 33 % ) ; 11 % say they sympathize with neither, while 8 % sympathize with both and 17 % do not offer an opinion.

title: Neg ative Characteristics Associated with Muslims (Non-Mus lim Respondents) Positive Characteristics Ass ociated with Muslims
question: What are opinions about the negative and positive characteristics associated with Muslims?
Gold Standard: The results show that many non - Muslims associate negative traits with Muslims . Majorities in Nigeria , India , Spain , Russia , and Germany see Muslims as violent . Large numbers , including majorities in India , Nigeria , and Russia , also consider Muslims arrogant . Many also associate selfishness with Muslims , although India is the only country where a majority does so . Non - Muslims are less likely to rate Muslims as greedy or immoral — in France for instance , only 10 % say Muslims are greedy and just 18 % label Muslims as immoral . The data on Muslim attitudes towards Westerners also reveal a variety of negative views . In the five majority Muslim countries , as well as Nigeria , at least 40 % of Muslims characterize Westerners as arrogant , violent , greedy , and immoral ; meanwhile , relatively few say Westerners are generous or honest . Muslims in these countries are also especially likely to say Westerners are selfish — in all six countries , majorities suggest selfishness is common among people in Europe and the United States . Negative assessments of Westerners are fairly common across all six of these countries , although they are slightly more prevalent in Jordan and Indonesia .
T5_BBOX: Nearly four - in - ten Muslims in Germany ( 42 % ), France ( 38 % ) and Spain ( 43 % ) say they have positive characteristics associated with Muslims.
T5: Majorities in Nigeria, India, Spain, Russia, and Germany see Muslims as violent. Large numbers, including majorities in India, Nigeria, and Russia, also consider Muslims arrogant. Non - Muslims are less likely to rate Muslims as greedy or immoral — in France for instance, only 10 % say Muslims are greedy and just 18 % label Muslims as immoral. title: Russian Views of China and the U.S. Russians with afavorable view of

Gold Standard: China is gaining popularity in Russia as attitudes toward the U.S. turn sharply negative . T5_BBOX: Currently, 71 % of Russians have a favorable view of China, while 61 % have a favorable view of the U.S.

title: Share of adults living in middle-income households is unchanged since 2011
question: Describe the changes in American income level from 1971 to 2011?
Gold Standard: From 1971 to 2011 , the share of adults in the middle class fell by 10 percentage points . But that shift was not all down the economic ladder . The increase in the share of adults who are upper income was greater than the increase in the share who are lower income over that period , a sign of economic progress overall .
T5_BBOX: From 1971 to 2011, the share of adults living in middle - income households has remained unchanged. In 2011, 59 % of adults lived in middle - income households, up from 29 % in 1971.
T5: About half ( 52 % ) of American adults lived in middle - class households in 2016. This is virtually unchanged from the 51 % who were middle class in 2011.

title: Americans split on whether fact-checkers favor one side; most Republicans say this is the case
question: Describe the trend among Americans towards data-checking organizations?
Gold Standard: Overall , Americans are split in their views of fact - checkers : Half say fact - checking efforts by news outlets and other organizations tend to deal fairly with all sides , while about the same portion ( 48 % ) say they tend to favor one side
T5_BBOX: About four - in - ten Americans ( 48 % ) say fact - checking efforts by news outlets and other organizations deal fairly with all sides.
T5: Seven - in - ten Republicans say fact - checkers tend to favor one side, compared with roughly three - in - ten Democrats ( 29 % ) – a 41 percentage point difference. Conversely, most Democrats ( 69 % ) say fact - checkers deal fairly with all sides, a view shared by just 28 % of Republicans. Independents are more split, with 47 % saying fact - checkers tend to favor one side and 51 % saying they deal fairly with all sides.

T5: Young voters are significantly less engaged in this year ’s election than at a comparable point in 2008 and now lag far behind older voters in interest in the campaign and intention to vote. The share of voters younger than 30 who are following campaign news very closely is roughly half what it was at this point four years ago ( 18 %, down from 35 % ). Just 63 % of young registered voters say they definitely plan to vote this year, down from 72 % four years ago.

title: Russian Views of China and the U.S. Russians with afavorable view of
question: How have Russians' views of China and the U.S. changed?
Gold Standard: China is gaining popularity in Russia as attitudes toward the U.S. turn sharply negative . In just the past two years , favorable views of China have jumped 17 percentage points among Russians , from 62 % in 2013 to an all - time high of 79 % today . Meanwhile , favorable views of the U.S. have taken a nosedive , falling from 51 % in 2013 , to 23 % in 2014 , to an all - time low of 15 % today .
T5_BBOX: Currently, 71 % of Russians have a favorable view of China, while 61 % have a favorable view of the U.S.
T5: In just the past two years, favorable views of China have jumped 17 percentage points among Russians, from 62 % in 2013 to an all - time high of 79 % today. title: Democrats now about as likely to sympathize with Palestinians as Israel side do you sympathize with more? (%) Democrats
question: Tell some information about Democrats now about as likely to sympathize with Palestinians as Israel side do you sympathize with more?
Gold Standard: For the first time in Pew Research Center surveys , Democrats are about as likely to say they sympathize more with the Palestinians ( 31 % ) than with Israel ( 33 % ) ; 11 % say they sympathize with neither , while 8 % sympathize with both and 17 % do not offer an opinion . The share of Democrats who say they sympathize more with Israel is down 10 points from April 2016 . The share who say they sympathize more with the Palestinians is little changed from last April ( 29 % ) , but is up significantly from July 2014 when just 17 % said they sympathized more with the Palestinians . By contrast , Republicans continue to overwhelmingly say they sympathize more with Israel ( 74 % ) than the Palestinians ( 11 % ) . There has been little movement in views among Republicans in recent years , but the share who say they sympathize more with Israel is now higher than in the mid-2000s and prior . For example , in 2005 , 57 % of Republicans said they sympathized more with Israel in their dispute with the Palestinians . As a result of these trends , there is now a 41 - point gap between the shares of Republicans ( 74 % ) and Democrats ( 33 % ) who say they sympathize more with Israel .
T5_BBOX: Democrats are now about as likely to sympathize with the Palestinians as they are to sympathize with Israel ( 33 % vs. 38 % ).

title: Share of adults living in middle-income households is unchanged since 2011

Muslims in these countries are also especially likely to say Westerners are selfish — in all six countries , majorities suggest selfishness is common among people in Europe and the United States . title: Democrats now about as likely to sympathize with Palestinians as Israel side do you sympathize with more? (%) Democrats
question: Tell some information about Democrats now about as likely to sympathize with Palestinians as Israel side do you sympathize with more?
Gold Standard: For the first time in Pew Research Center surveys , Democrats are about as likely to say they sympathize more with the Palestinians ( 31 % ) than with Israel ( 33 % ) ; 11 % say they sympathize with neither , while 8 % sympathize with both and 17 % do not offer an opinion . The share of Democrats who say they sympathize more with Israel is down 10 points from April 2016 . The share who say they sympathize more with the Palestinians is little changed from last April ( 29 % ) , but is up significantly from July 2014 when just 17 % said they sympathized more with the Palestinians . By contrast , Republicans continue to overwhelmingly say they sympathize more with Israel ( 74 % ) than the Palestinians ( 11 % ) . There has been little movement in views among Republicans in recent years , but the share who say they sympathize more with Israel is now higher than in the mid-2000s and prior . For example , in 2005 , 57 % of Republicans said they sympathized more with Israel in their dispute with the Palestinians . As a result of these trends , there is now a 41 - point gap between the shares of Republicans ( 74 % ) and Democrats ( 33 % ) who say they sympathize more with Israel .
T5_BBOX: Democrats are now about as likely to sympathize with the Palestinians as they are to sympathize with Israel ( 33 % vs. 38 % ).
T5: For the first time in Pew Research Center surveys, Democrats are about as likely to say they sympathize more with the Palestinians ( 31 % ) than with Israel ( 33 % ) ; 11 % say they sympathize with neither, while 8 % sympathize with both and 17 % do not offer an opinion.

Gold Standard: President Barack Obama ’s overall approval rating has held steady at 44 % . While Obama ’s job rating has been below 50 % for the past year , it stands eight points higher than that of his predecessor , Bush , at a comparable point eight years ago . In July 2006 , 36 % approved of Bush ’s job performance .
T5_BBOX: Obama ’s approval rating for his second term has been much higher than that of George W. Bush ’s ( 60 % approval vs. 40 % approval ). Obama ’s approval rating for his second term has been much higher than that of Bush ’s ( 30 % approval vs. 10 % approval ).

title: Is Iraq Another Vie stnam? Is Iraq 4 Civil War? Mostly a civil war Iraq willbe ano ther Vie tram
question: What is the public opinion on the Iraq civil war?
Gold Standard: The latest national survey by the Pew Research Center for the People & amp ; the Press , conducted Dec. 6 - 10 among 1,502 adults , finds that 52 % currently describe the violence in Iraq as “ mostly a civil war , ” rather than an insurgency against the U.S. and its allies . While this is largely unchanged from September , it represents a major shift from a year ago . In December 2005 , just 30 % viewed the violence in Iraq as mostly a civil war while 58 % said it was an insurgency aimed at the U.S. and its allies .
T5_BBOX: Currently, 52 % say the U.S. will accomplish its goals in Iraq, while 35 % say it will be mostly an insurgency.
T5: 52 % currently describe the violence in Iraq as “ mostly a civil war, ” rather than an insurgency against the U.S. and its allies.

title: Solid Liberals, Core Conservatives highly focused on control of Congress in 2018 which party wins control of

title: Russian Views of China and the U.S. Russians with afavorable view of
question: How have Russians' views of China and the U.S. changed?
Gold Standard: China is gaining popularity in Russia as attitudes toward the U.S. turn sharply negative . In just the past two years , favorable views of China have jumped 17 percentage points among Russians , from 62 % in 2013 to an all - time high of 79 % today . Meanwhile , favorable views of the U.S. have taken a nosedive , falling from 51 % in 2013 , to 23 % in 2014 , to an all - time low of 15 % today .
T5_BBOX: Currently, 71 % of Russians have a favorable view of China, while 61 % have a favorable view of the U.S.
T5: In just the past two years, favorable views of China have jumped 17 percentage points among Russians, from 62 % in 2013 to an all - time high of 79 % today. Meanwhile, favorable views of the U.S. have taken a nosedive, falling from 51 % in 2013, to 23 % in 2014, to an all - time low of 15 % today.

title: Neg ative Characteristics Associated with Muslims (Non-Mus lim Respondents) Positive Characteristics Ass ociated with Muslims
question: What are opinions about the negative and positive characteristics associated with Muslims?
Gold Standard: The results show that many non - Muslims associate negative traits with Muslims . Majorities in Nigeria , India , Spain , Russia , and Germany see Muslims as violent . Large numbers , including majorities in India , Nigeria , and Russia , also consider Muslims arrogant . Many also associate selfishness with Muslims , although India is the only country where a majority does so . Non - Muslims are less likely to rate Muslims as greedy or immoral — in France for instance , only 10 % say Muslims are greedy and just 18 % label Muslims as immoral . The data on Muslim attitudes towards Westerners also reveal a variety of negative views . In the five majority Muslim countries , as well as Nigeria , at least 40 % of Muslims characterize Westerners as arrogant , violent , greedy , and immoral ; meanwhile , relatively few say Westerners are generous or honest . Muslims in these countries are also especially likely to say Westerners are selfish — in all six countries , majorities suggest selfishness is common among people in Europe and the United States . Negative assessments of Westerners are fairly common across all six of these countries , although they are slightly more prevalent in Jordan and Indonesia .
T5_BBOX: Nearly four - in - ten Muslims in Germany ( 42 % ), France ( 38 % ) and Spain ( 43 % ) say they have positive characteristics associated with Muslims.
T5: Majorities in Nigeria, India, Spain, Russia, and Germany see Muslims as violent. Large numbers, including majorities in India, Nigeria, and Russia, also consider Muslims arrogant. question: Write some details about Democrats concerned their party will not do enough to oppose Trump?
Gold Standard: For their part , Democrats are far more concerned that congressional Democrats will not do enough , rather than go too far , to oppose Trump . The latest survey by Pew Research Center , conducted Feb. 7 - 12 among 1,503 adults , shows how members of both parties are coming to grips with Washington ’s changed political dynamics : Democrats want their party to challenge Trump . Nearly three - quarters of Democrats and Democratic leaners ( 72 % ) say their bigger concern is that congressional Democrats will not do enough to oppose Trump and his policies . Just 20 % say they are more concerned that Democrats in Congress will go too far opposing Trump and his policies .

title: Democrats now about as likely to sympathize with Palestinians as Israel side do you sympathize with more? (%) Democrats
question: Tell some information about Democrats now about as likely to sympathize with Palestinians as Israel side do you sympathize with more?
Gold Standard: For the first time in Pew Research Center surveys , Democrats are about as likely to say they sympathize more with the Palestinians ( 31 % ) than with Israel ( 33 % ) ; 11 % say they sympathize with neither , while 8 % sympathize with both and 17 % do not offer an opinion . The share of Democrats who say they sympathize more with Israel is down 10 points from April 2016 . The share who say they sympathize more with the Palestinians is little changed from last April ( 29 % ) , but is up significantly from July 2014 when just 17 % said they sympathized more with the Palestinians . By contrast , Republicans continue to overwhelmingly say they sympathize more with Israel ( 74 % ) than the Palestinians ( 11 % ) . There has been little movement in views among Republicans in recent years , but the share who say they sympathize more with Israel is now higher than in the mid-2000s and prior . For example , in 2005 , 57 % of Republicans said they sympathized more with Israel in their dispute with the Palestinians . As a result of these trends , there is now a 41 - point gap between the shares of Republicans ( 74 % ) and Democrats ( 33 % ) who say they sympathize more with Israel .
T5_BBOX: Democrats are now about as likely to sympathize with the Palestinians as they are to sympathize with Israel ( 33 % vs. 38 % ).
T5: For the first time in Pew Research Center surveys, Democrats are about as likely to say they sympathize more with the Palestinians ( 31 % ) than with Israel ( 33 % ) ; 11 % say they sympathize with neither, while 8 % sympathize with both and 17 % do not offer an opinion.

title: Social networking site use by age group, 2005-2011 The percentage of adult internet users in each age group who use social networking sites
question: How is the use of social networks characterized by different age groups?
Gold Standard: Social networking sites have been very popular with young adults ages 18 - 29 almost since their inception . Between February 2005 and August 2006 , the use of social networking sites among young adult internet users ages 18 - 29 jumped from 9 % to 49 % ; during this same time period , use of these sites by 30 - 49 year olds remained essentially unchanged . Since then , users under age 30 have continued to be significantly more likely to use social networking sites when compared with every other adult age group . As of May 2011 , over eight in ten internet users ages 18 - 29 use social networking sites ( 83 % ) , compared with seven in ten 30 - 49 year - olds ( 70 % ) , half of 50 - 64 year - olds ( 51 % ) , and a third of those age 65 and older ( 33 % ) .
T5_BBOX: The share of internet users ages 65 and older who use social networking sites has risen significantly in recent years. In 2005, 83 % of internet users ages 65 and older used social networking sites, compared with 61 % of internet users ages 18 to 29. In 2011, the share of internet users ages 30 to 49 increased to 47 %.

title: Neg ative Characteristics Associated with Muslims (Non-Mus lim Respondents) Positive Characteristics Ass ociated with Muslims
question: What are opinions about the negative and positive characteristics associated with Muslims?
Gold Standard: The results show that many non - Muslims associate negative traits with Muslims . Majorities in Nigeria , India , Spain , Russia , and Germany see Muslims as violent . Large numbers , including majorities in India , Nigeria , and Russia , also consider Muslims arrogant . Many also associate selfishness with Muslims , although India is the only country where a majority does so . Non - Muslims are less likely to rate Muslims as greedy or immoral — in France for instance , only 10 % say Muslims are greedy and just 18 % label Muslims as immoral . The data on Muslim attitudes towards Westerners also reveal a variety of negative views . In the five majority Muslim countries , as well as Nigeria , at least 40 % of Muslims characterize Westerners as arrogant , violent , greedy , and immoral ; meanwhile , relatively few say Westerners are generous or honest . Muslims in these countries are also especially likely to say Westerners are selfish — in all six countries , majorities suggest selfishness is common among people in Europe and the United States . Negative assessments of Westerners are fairly common across all six of these countries , although they are slightly more prevalent in Jordan and Indonesia .
T5_BBOX: Nearly four - in - ten Muslims in Germany ( 42 % ), France ( 38 % ) and Spain ( 43 % ) say they have positive characteristics associated with Muslims.
T5: Majorities in Nigeria, India, Spain, Russia, and Germany see Muslims as violent. Large numbers, including majorities in India, Nigeria, and Russia, also consider Muslims arrogant. Non - Muslims are less likely to rate Muslims as greedy or immoral — in France for instance, only 10 % say Muslims are greedy and just 18 % label Muslims as immoral.
